dialogue: Sure wish I did.
Brazilian Bar Association. Can you put the coffee on?
Sure, Mrs. Paiva. Want me to fix you dinner?
He went out for a bit.
I'm a bundle of nerves, Mrs. Paiva, my hand won't stop shaking.
Stay calm. You take care of the kids, and I'll deal with these men.
Mrs. Paiva?
I'm sorry, it's just that everyone's already asleep--
-Can I get one?
I'm in dire need of a shower.
Is Eliana here?
Yes. She said you were coming back with Rubens.
How is she?
She's never at home anymore. Always out playing volleyball.
And the little ones?
Shaken up.
What about Vera? Have you heard from her?
She called the other day... I told her you'd gone to São Paulo.
You did the right thing. I'm so sorry about all this. Were those men here for very long?
No, they left right after they took you all. And how are you?
I can't even begin to thank you. Call a cab and go get some rest.
Nalu's in your bed. Since you've been gone, she only sleeps there.
Sweetie. C'mere.
I just need to take a shower.
Mr. Machado's out front. Should I put some coffee on?
No need, we're heading out.
I'll pick the kids up at school. Just taker care of lunch, please.
What would you like me to make?
Whatever there is.
Not for children's ears, honey.
Where's the key?
Does it even have one?
Let me do it.
What about that car with those men in it?
It's been there for days, Mrs. Paiva.
But do they do anything?
They just sit there. Staring over here all day.
Your apron's frayed. I told you should buy a new one.
The cash ran out, so I had to use the money Mr. Paiva gave me to buy groceries while you were away. There wasn't enough for a new one.
Of course. I'll go by the bank tomorrow and get us some more cash.
And... Mrs. Paiva, could you see about my pay, too? I know you've got an awful lot on your plate, but Mr. Paiva only paid me through December.
I'm sorry Zezé, I'll sort it out.
Thank you.
